item.title: Netherlands to ban the burka
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:50, topic:414957”][quote author=yo123 link=topic=516916.msg3757461#msg3757461 date=1316580395]

It should be their choice to wear what they want if it doesn’t infringe on the rights of other people (like going nude etc).

maybe I’m reading that wrong but how is going nude infringing on the rights of other people?
[/quote]the right to walk down the street without going WTFOMFGROFLMAOGROSS!! Amendment 28 of the US Constitution, niggas

There is not a right to not being offended.[/quote]

No, but there probably is a law against it. Complete freedom would mean that you’d be allowed to walk the streets naked. But sometimes freedoms need exceptions, which is the case with public nudity. Hygiene etc…

To go back to this particular ban, there are a few problems with it that makes it illegal. The plan is to ban every piece of clothing that completely covers the face. This also includes motorcycle helmets, face covering shawls (we don’t have winters that are that harsh, but sometimes low temperatures combined with a strong wind are painful) and carnaval clothing. The ban already includes an exception for carnaval. Besides that, the odds of people wearing a helmet or shawl getting fined are very slim, close to none existent. Which means that the reason for the ban isn’t the ability to identify someone, but it’s a specific ban of the burka. Obviously, the burka is strictly tied to Islam and thus it’s discrimination. One complaint to the European Court of Human Rights, or even the human rights council and the ban is wiped off the table.

item.title: Netherlands to ban the burka
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

Generally, followers of any organized religion pick and choose. Whether or not you choose to ignore the bad parts doesn’t qualify or disqualify it from still being regressive and dogmatic.

That being said, as Moparisthebest, Speljohan, Mopman, etc. pointed out, a free society cannot pick and choose as such. Restricting such things like the Nazi swastika and Italian fascii symbols is censorship. A free society in this context uses a specific type of freedom – /negative/ liberty, i.e. of the “don’t-tread-on-me” fashion.

Still, what about /positive/ liberties? Like others have said, including Miss Silabsoft, government intervention in such issues can prevent these women from being oppressed by their husbands and what not. For them, it’s not so much belief as it is indoctrination. They are forced into it from an early age by their family due to their culture. Many are innocent and naive, though, and can’t even imagine what liberation would be like.

Is it our duty to provide them the positive liberty from such oppression? Or is this interfering with their negative liberties? Do you leave people unknowingly despotised by their ignorance or is it your duty to save them? I doubt we’ll come to a consensus any time soon.
